comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: It certainly looks like a roulette wheel.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: An account of a court case at Down Assizes (Freeman's , Wednesday, March 11, 1840) centres around a "fraudulently constructed" roulette table at Downpatrick races, by means of which James Perkins cheated several people "of divers sums of money". Here's a snippet including a description of the dodgy roulette wheel. So roulette at a racecourse wasn't unheard of. BTW later in the account , after a witness was asked if he had played in the tent A pause ensued, which was sufficiently significant to cause the court to be convulsed with laughter, which was joined by the learned judge himself The defence counsel argued that a tent was not a house, so it wasn't covered by legislation concerning gaming houses. The judge sentenced Perkins to 3 months imprisonment and £100 fine, but the sentence was suspended pending a decision from the Court of Queen's Bench.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: And in an account of "The Card-Cheating Case at Brighton" (Freeman's Monday, July 26, 1852) a witness says he had played roulette at races before this, and generally lost; he had never heard of anybody that won (a laugh). This suggests that roulette wheels at races (a) were commonplace and (b) fixed

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: ... and in 1862 The plaintiff , on examination, stated that he kept a roulette table at races, and also used "bones" (dice) at races; was last convicted of gambling at Limerick; gave up going to races September last; he went to races with a roulette table for the purpose of opposing parties who had robbed him of £600 ... The jury found for the plaintiff one farthing damages

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Roulette at Punchestown (Freeman's Tuesday, April 29, 1873). The defendants claimed they had been running roulette tables openly at Punchestown for 10 years (the 1868 date falls nicely in the middle of their career), and had paid the Hunt committee £10 for the privilege of having a tent there.

comment._content: Great, thanks! Think we can safely say this was a roulette wheel and table then...

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] I saw that, but didn't think it would provide a stable enough support for the wheel. On the other hand, I expect stability was the last thing the croupier required, probably preferring some means of providing some "encouragement" for the ball to fall into the "right" slot.
